When the “A” Word Slaps You in the Face

Christina Hausauer
Apr 2

ABUSE

It’s not always about the bruises, or neglect, or the suffering of pain.

It is about power. It is about control.

Mental or psychological abuse comes in many forms. It can be caused by constantly being told that you aren’t capable of standing on your own. It can be a result of being continually compared to others who are more significant, or “better” than you are. It can be an ongoing struggle to feel like you are valued and worthy of love and happiness.

If you have followed my wok about healing from child abuse, and even abuse as a young adult, you will know that I am knowledgeable about surviving abuse, and what that looks like. My abuse as a child was violent, aggressive and horrifying. I worked hard to put that life behind me and start fresh.

That is, I suppose, until the past years with my partner happened.

What I Knew

I knew he liked control. My friends told me often that he wasn’t respectful toward me, and it pained them to hear the way he spoke to me. He talked “at me” and not “with me”. It was just his way, and I succumbed.

I knew he liked to have sex, all the time, whether or not I wanted to. I knew he felt my body was his, and he toyed with it in a way that made me uncomfortable, but I laughed it off, stifled, and seethed when he wasn’t looking.

I knew he struggled with his past marital break down, and kept his ex at arm’s length. She was always an apparition in our home, and the standard that was set for me to be at.

I knew he liked things on his terms, and felt that my opinions were just “talk”, unworthy of his attention.

I knew he liked to keep me to himself, even jealous of my daughter’s affections.

But, ABUSE???

My therapist said to me, two weeks ago during a session, “Christina, you are leaving an abusive relationship. I am so proud of you”.

That WORD- ABUSE

I reeled like she slapped me in the face with that one word.

D? Abusive? What?!?!?!

After I stopped shaking, she explained the power. She talked about how he made me feel when it came to his ex wife. She reminded me of how he spoke to me. She gave him the title and it made my head spin.

I felt myself falling backwards down a dark hole that I worked so damn hard to crawl out of. It took me until I was in my 30’s to finally crawl out of that hole, yet here I was again.

I felt stupid. I felt betrayed. I felt terrified that I didn’t see it.

Blind Sided

There is something so dirty and disgusting about the word abuse.

It is a simple 5 letter word in the English dictionary, yet it holds so much power on its own. Hearing from a professional source, who has seen me cry, heard me yell and swear, and has listened to my past years with D, was a major turning point. It made me realize that walking away was the only answer.

I had to remove myself from a situation where I was being controlled and programmed.

So, I did.

I have never recounted the details of my abuse, with D. I just told him the information that I felt comfortable with. Now, it makes me wonder if he saw me as prey? Did he play on the victim side of me, or did I allow him to, because I wanted to finally trust someone? I have no idea.

I was blind sided by the “title” abusive relationship.

He Keeps Telling Me to “Get Better”

Every day, he messages me, and I just deal with it. He continually tells me to “Get better”.

Looking back over the past, I realized a few things about myself:

  1. I always had walls up
  2. I lied and kept secrets for fear of judgement
  3. I rarely laughed hard, or cried hard.
  4. I never shared deep thoughts or feelings with him, yet I would tell my friends EVERYTHING
  5. I never allowed myself to completely fall in love with him. My heart has always been wrapped in armor. His ex wife was the catalyst for the steel around the depths of my heart.
  6. I often felt as though he was a parent to me
  7. He would keep tabs on how much I drank and where I was with my friends at all times-convinced I would cheat on him.
  8. He cheated on me 3 times that I know of
  9. I always had his ex wife looming over me, in our house and in my head
  10. I never felt valued or nurtured- protected, yes. But not nurtured.

He has been trying to find a pathway into my heart, but I am on lock down. That word has me full of rage and regret. The word abuse has put me into a spiral of frustration that I thought was behind me. It has weakened me, but I have fought with worse, and I will fight this too. It has made me look back and reflect on my years in a home filled with control and being at his beck and call.

Never again.

Since I have been away, I feel EVERYTHING. I feel when someone says “I love you,” and I know they mean it. I laugh til I cry, and I cry til I fall asleep, safe and alone. I have the freedom to make as many choices in a day that I wish to, or not. I have the capacity to write again, and to organize my feelings, as I figure out my life.

I was paranoid for the first while, being alone, as I felt that he had constant surveillance on me. Finally, that is starting to subside, although I never sit behind an unlocked door.

I have been medicated for high anxiety for the past year, and for the first time, I don’t feel like a robot. I feel. Period.

I think I am “getting better”.

Just not in the way that he wants me to be.
